clusters.title: Israel calls up 60,000 reservists ahead of planned Gaza City offensive
clusters.neutral_headline: Israel Plans Gaza City Takeover, Calls Up Reservists

items.title: Israel calls up 60,000 reservists ahead of planned Gaza City offensive
items.standfirst: The military says troops are already operating in some areas ahead of the planned operation to occupy all of the city.
items.content: The military says troops are already operating in some areas ahead of the planned operation to occupy all of the city.

items.title: Israel to call up 60,000 reservists in plan to expand war, seize Gaza City
items.standfirst: Israel's military says it will call up 60,000 reservists and lengthen the service of an additional 20,000 reservists.
items.content: Israel's military says it will call up 60,000 reservists and lengthen the service of an additional 20,000 reservists.

items.title: Israel to call up 60,000 reservists ahead of Gaza City invasion
items.standfirst: Plan for renewed assault comes after Hamas said it had accepted proposal for ceasefire and hostage deal
items.content: Plan for renewed assault comes after Hamas said it had accepted proposal for ceasefire and hostage deal

items.title: Israel approves plan for Gaza City takeover and call-up of 60,000 reservists
items.standfirst: TEL AVIV — Israel has approved a plan for the takeover of Gaza City that includes calling up 60,000 reservists for its expanded military operation in the besieged Palestinian enclave.
items.content: TEL AVIV — Israel has approved a plan for the takeover of Gaza City that includes calling up 60,000 reservists for its expanded military operation in the besieged Palestinian enclave.

items.title: Israeli military will call up 50,000 reservists as it plans new phase of war in Gaza
items.standfirst: An Israeli military official says the country’s top generals have approved plans to call up tens of thousands of reservists in order to begin a new phase of operations in some of Gaza’s most densely populated areas. From Jerusalem, FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky has the details.
items.content: An Israeli military official says the country’s top generals have approved plans to call up tens of thousands of reservists in order to begin a new phase of operations in some of Gaza’s most densely populated areas. From Jerusalem, FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky has the details.

items.title: Israeli military will call up 50,000 reservists as it plans new phase of war in Gaza
items.standfirst: An Israeli official said that the military will be operating in parts of Gaza City where the Israeli military has not yet operated and where Hamas is still active.
items.content: An Israeli official said that the military will be operating in parts of Gaza City where the Israeli military has not yet operated and where Hamas is still active.(Image credit: Ariel Schalit)

items.title: Israel approves plan to conquer Gaza City, call up around 60,000 reservists
items.standfirst: Israel's defence minister on Wednesday approved plans to conquer Gaza city and call up around 60,000 reservists. The new plans come as international mediators are piling pressure on Israel to respond to a ceasefire deal that has been accepted by Hamas.
items.content: Israel's defence minister on Wednesday approved plans to conquer Gaza city and call up around 60,000 reservists. The new plans come as international mediators are piling pressure on Israel to respond to a ceasefire deal that has been accepted by Hamas.

items.title: Israel demands release of all Gaza hostages, casting doubt on ceasefire proposal
items.standfirst: It comes a day after Hamas said it accepted a proposal for a 60-day truce, during which around half of the 50 hostages would be freed.
items.content: It comes a day after Hamas said it accepted a proposal for a 60-day truce, during which around half of the 50 hostages would be freed.

items.title: Senior mediator spells out Gaza ceasefire proposal agreed to by Hamas
items.standfirst: There was a muted response from Israel after Hamas said it had agreed to the latest proposal for a ceasefire in Gaza and to free the remaining hostages.
items.content: There was a muted response from Israel after Hamas said it had agreed to the latest proposal for a ceasefire in Gaza and to free the remaining hostages.

items.title: Mediators optimistic Israel will accept ceasefire deal that is ‘almost identical’ to one they earlier agreed – as it happened
items.standfirst: Qatar says no breakthrough has yet been made but Hamas has given ‘positive response’The UN’s human rights office on Tuesday condemned a far-right Israeli minister for taunting a Palestinian prisoner in his cell and sharing the footage online, Reuters reports.National security minister Itamar Ben-Gvir published a video on Friday last week showing him confronting Marwan Barghouti, the most high-profile Palestinian detainee in Israeli custody. Continue reading...
items.content: Qatar says no breakthrough has yet been made but Hamas has given ‘positive response’The UN’s human rights office on Tuesday condemned a far-right Israeli minister for taunting a Palestinian prisoner in his cell and sharing the footage online, Reuters reports.National security minister Itamar Ben-Gvir published a video on Friday last week showing him confronting Marwan Barghouti, the most high-profile Palestinian detainee in Israeli custody. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel to respond by Friday over Gaza truce plan accepted by Hamas
items.standfirst: Israel under pressure to accept ceasefire proposal that is said to be almost identical to earlier US-backed planMiddle East crisis – live updatesIsrael has said it will deliver its response to international mediators by Friday over a new Gaza ceasefire plan accepted by Hamas amid mounting pressure for a truce in a war that has claimed more than 62,000 Palestinian lives.After mass protests in Israel demanding a deal to secure the release of the remaining 20 living Israeli hostages held in Gaza, it appeared that Hamas had reduced its demands over a prisoners-for-hostages exchange as well as over the scope of an Israeli-demanded “security buffer zone”. Continue reading...
items.content: Israel under pressure to accept ceasefire proposal that is said to be almost identical to earlier US-backed planMiddle East crisis – live updatesIsrael has said it will deliver its response to international mediators by Friday over a new Gaza ceasefire plan accepted by Hamas amid mounting pressure for a truce in a war that has claimed more than 62,000 Palestinian lives.After mass protests in Israel demanding a deal to secure the release of the remaining 20 living Israeli hostages held in Gaza, it appeared that Hamas had reduced its demands over a prisoners-for-hostages exchange as well as over the scope of an Israeli-demanded “security buffer zone”. Continue reading...

items.title: Gaza ceasefire proposal agreed by Hamas 'almost identical' to US special envoy's, Qatar says
items.standfirst: A latest Gaza ceasefire proposal approved by Hamas is "almost identical" to that put forward by US special envoy Steve Witkoff, a spokesperson for Qatar's foreign ministry has said.
items.content: A latest Gaza ceasefire proposal approved by Hamas is "almost identical" to that put forward by US special envoy Steve Witkoff, a spokesperson for Qatar's foreign ministry has said.

items.title: Hamas tells mediators it approves latest Gaza ceasefire proposal – as it happened
items.standfirst: Hamas official tells Reuters news agency it has approved latest Gaza ceasefire proposal. This live blog is closedHamas says it accepts proposal for Gaza ceasefire and release of hostagesNorway’s sovereign wealth fund, the world’s largest, said on Monday it had decided to exclude six companies with connections to the West Bank and Gaza from its portfolio, following a review of its Israeli investments.The $2tn wealth fund did not name the companies it had decided to exclude, but said these would be made public once the divestment was completed, Reuters reports. Continue reading...
items.content: Hamas official tells Reuters news agency it has approved latest Gaza ceasefire proposal. This live blog is closedHamas says it accepts proposal for Gaza ceasefire and release of hostagesNorway’s sovereign wealth fund, the world’s largest, said on Monday it had decided to exclude six companies with connections to the West Bank and Gaza from its portfolio, following a review of its Israeli investments.The $2tn wealth fund did not name the companies it had decided to exclude, but said these would be made public once the divestment was completed, Reuters reports. Continue reading...

items.title: Hamas says it accepts proposal for Gaza ceasefire and release of hostages
items.standfirst: Deal would include 60-day halt to violence and exchange of half of living Israeli hostages for Palestinian prisonersHamas officials say they have accepted a proposal for a Gaza ceasefire deal that would include the release of half of the approximately 20 remaining living Israeli hostages as part of a phased resolution to the war, as Gaza health officials said 62,000 Palestinians had died in the 22 months of war.The proposed deal follows negotiations between Hamas and Egyptian and Qatari officials that have been taking place in Cairo in recent days, and comes after the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, was confronted on Sunday by Israel’s biggest protests of the war, which called for a deal to secure the release of the hostages. Continue reading...
items.content: Deal would include 60-day halt to violence and exchange of half of living Israeli hostages for Palestinian prisonersHamas officials say they have accepted a proposal for a Gaza ceasefire deal that would include the release of half of the approximately 20 remaining living Israeli hostages as part of a phased resolution to the war, as Gaza health officials said 62,000 Palestinians had died in the 22 months of war.The proposed deal follows negotiations between Hamas and Egyptian and Qatari officials that have been taking place in Cairo in recent days, and comes after the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, was confronted on Sunday by Israel’s biggest protests of the war, which called for a deal to secure the release of the hostages. Continue reading...

items.title: Netanyahu criticises protests in Israel against his handling of Gaza war
items.standfirst: Israeli PM suggests demonstrators are toughening Hamas’s stance and delaying the release of hostagesBenjamin Netanyahu has criticised massive street protests against his handling of the Gaza war, and failure to secure the release of remaining Israeli hostages, suggesting demonstrators were giving comfort to Hamas’s position in negotiations.The Israeli prime minister made his comments against the backdrop of the largest protests in almost two years of war, with estimates that upwards of 400,000 people joined marches across Israel on Sunday. Continue reading...
items.content: Israeli PM suggests demonstrators are toughening Hamas’s stance and delaying the release of hostagesBenjamin Netanyahu has criticised massive street protests against his handling of the Gaza war, and failure to secure the release of remaining Israeli hostages, suggesting demonstrators were giving comfort to Hamas’s position in negotiations.The Israeli prime minister made his comments against the backdrop of the largest protests in almost two years of war, with estimates that upwards of 400,000 people joined marches across Israel on Sunday. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Israel approved a plan to take over Gaza City, expanding military operations.
The plan includes calling up approximately 60,000 reservists for the operation.
Military officials approved plans to begin a new phase of operations in Gaza.
Hamas accepted a proposal for a ceasefire and hostage deal, according to reports.
Israel demands the release of all hostages, casting doubt on the ceasefire proposal.

Trump ruled out putting US troops on the ground in Ukraine, but the White House left the door open to…

items.title: U.S. and allies meet on security guarantees as Trump arranges a Putin-Zelenskyy summit
items.standfirst: United States and NATO officials were set to meet Wednesday to discuss security guarantees for Ukraine as the White House worked to arrange a summit between Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Russia's Vladimir Putin.
items.content: United States and NATO officials were set to meet Wednesday to discuss security guarantees for Ukraine as the White House worked to arrange a summit between Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Russia's Vladimir Putin.

items.title: Russia, Switzerland, Austria: where might Ukraine peace talks take place?
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump's recent efforts to broker peace in Ukraine has led to speculation over where a potential face-to-face meeting between Russian President Vladimir Putin and and his Ukrainian counterpart Volodymyr Zelensky might take place. While Putin has suggested meeting in Moscow, European leaders are pushing for a Austria of Switzerland to host talks.
items.content: US President Donald Trump's recent efforts to broker peace in Ukraine has led to speculation over where a potential face-to-face meeting between Russian President Vladimir Putin and and his Ukrainian counterpart Volodymyr Zelensky might take place. While Putin has suggested meeting in Moscow, European leaders are pushing for a Austria of Switzerland to host talks.

items.title: Trump and Zelenskyy's meeting with European leaders marks a historic moment

items.content: European leaders joined Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in Washington on Monday in a rare display of unity to end the war with Russia.

items.title: Some in Congress expressing cautious optimism for possible Ukraine-Russia peace deal
items.standfirst: Some congressional leaders are expressing cautious optimism about a possible deal to end Russia's war with Ukraine following President Trump's recent meetings with Vladimir Putin and Volodymyr Zelenskyy. CBS News congressional correspondent Nikole Killion reports.
items.content: Some congressional leaders are expressing cautious optimism about a possible deal to end Russia's war with Ukraine following President Trump's recent meetings with Vladimir Putin and Volodymyr Zelenskyy. CBS News congressional correspondent Nikole Killion reports.

items.standfirst: President Trump and Ukraine’s President Zelenskyy held a White House meeting that was much warmer in tone then their showdown a few months ago. Trump said there does not need to be a ceasefire to move forward with a peace deal, while suggesting he would support security guarantees for Ukraine. NBC Nightly News anchor Tom Llamas reports.

items.title: National intelligence director strips security clearances from 37 current and former national security officials – US politics live
items.standfirst: Tulsi Gabbard accuses officials, some of whom worked on intelligence community’s assessment of Russian interference in 2016 election, of ‘politicizing intelligence’The White House launched an official TikTok account on Tuesday, as Donald Trump continues to permit the Chinese-owned platform to operate in the US despite a law requiring its sale.“America we are BACK! What’s up TikTok?” read a caption on the account’s first post, a 27-second clip, on the popular video-sharing app. Continue reading...

items.title: White House launches official TikTok account as Trump's deadline to ban app looms
items.standfirst: The White House launched an official TikTok account on Tuesday, less than a month before a Sept. 17 deadline for the app to either find a new owner or face a U.S.-wide ban.
items.content: The White House launched an official TikTok account on Tuesday, less than a month before a Sept. 17 deadline for the app to either find a new owner or face a U.S.-wide ban.

items.title: White House Launches TikTok Account With US Sale Uncertain
items.standfirst: The White House launched its own TikTok account on Tuesday, the latest signal of support as President Donald Trump continues to seek a sale of the social video app’s US operations from Chinese company ByteDance Ltd.
items.content: The White House launched its own TikTok account on Tuesday, the latest signal of support as President Donald Trump continues to seek a sale of the social video app’s US operations from Chinese company ByteDance Ltd.

clusters.title: 'In principle, there are always justifications for limiting & curtailing threats to nat'l security'
clusters.neutral_headline: Irish Rapper Faces Terrorism Charge in UK Court

items.title: 'In principle, there are always justifications for limiting & curtailing threats to nat'l security'
items.standfirst: A member of Irish rap group Kneecap was welcomed by hundreds of supporters as he arrived at a London court on Wednesday, charged with a terrorism offence for allegedly displaying a flag in support of Iran-backed Lebanese militia Hezbollah during a Kneecap concert in London in November 2024. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, FRANCE 24's Oliver Farry welcomes Ethan Shattock, Expert in free expression and Lecturer in the School of Law at the Queen's University Belfast.
items.content: A member of Irish rap group Kneecap was welcomed by hundreds of supporters as he arrived at a London court on Wednesday, charged with a terrorism offence for allegedly displaying a flag in support of Iran-backed Lebanese militia Hezbollah during a Kneecap concert in London in November 2024. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, FRANCE 24's Oliver Farry welcomes Ethan Shattock, Expert in free expression and Lecturer in the School of Law at the Queen's University Belfast.

items.title: Kneecap rapper arrives in court over terror charge
items.standfirst: Liam Óg Ó hAnnaidh was charged with a terror offence after allegedly displaying a flag in support of proscribed organisation Hezbollah.
items.content: Liam Óg Ó hAnnaidh was charged with a terror offence after allegedly displaying a flag in support of proscribed organisation Hezbollah.

clusters.title: Bus crash kills more than 70 Afghans deported from Iran, including 17 children
clusters.neutral_headline: Bus Crash in Afghanistan Kills Afghan Deportees

items.title: Bus crash kills more than 70 Afghans deported from Iran, including 17 children
items.standfirst: At least 75 people, including 17 children, have been killed in Afghanistan in a traffic accident involving a bus carrying migrants who were deported from Iran, officials said Wednesday.
items.content: At least 75 people, including 17 children, have been killed in Afghanistan in a traffic accident involving a bus carrying migrants who were deported from Iran, officials said Wednesday.

items.title: Dozens of Afghan deportees from Iran killed in bus crash
items.standfirst: At least 17 children were among those killed after the bus crashed and caught fire on its way to Kabul.
items.content: At least 17 children were among those killed after the bus crashed and caught fire on its way to Kabul.

items.title: Bus crash kills dozens of migrants just deported back to Afghanistan by Iran
items.standfirst: Seventy-six people were killed in a collision between a bus carrying Afghan migrants just deported by Iran and two other vehicles in western Afghanistan, officials say.
items.content: Seventy-six people were killed in a collision between a bus carrying Afghan migrants just deported by Iran and two other vehicles in western Afghanistan, officials say.

items.title: Scores die in bus crash carrying Afghan migrants returning home
items.standfirst: A collision between a bus and two other vehicles killed at least 78 people in western Afghanistan, local officials said on Wednesday. The bus was carrying Afghan migrants who had been living in Iran and were returning home to Kabul.
items.content: A collision between a bus and two other vehicles killed at least 78 people in western Afghanistan, local officials said on Wednesday. The bus was carrying Afghan migrants who had been living in Iran and were returning home to Kabul.

ai_summary: A bus crash in Afghanistan killed over 70 people.
The bus was carrying Afghan migrants deported from Iran.
At least 17 children were among those killed in the crash.
The crash involved the bus and two other vehicles.
The migrants were returning home to Kabul.

clusters.title: France probes live streaming death of man
clusters.neutral_headline: Investigation Launched into Death of French Streamer

items.title: France probes live streaming death of man
items.standfirst: Prosecutors in Nice are investigating the death of 46-year-old Raphael Graven, known online as “Jean Pormanove” or “JP,” who collapsed during a live-streamed show in which he was being mistreated. The video, broadcast on the platform Kick, showed him lying motionless under a blanket as one of two men in the room threw a bottle towards him.
items.content: Prosecutors in Nice are investigating the death of 46-year-old Raphael Graven, known online as “Jean Pormanove” or “JP,” who collapsed during a live-streamed show in which he was being mistreated. The video, broadcast on the platform Kick, showed him lying motionless under a blanket as one of two men in the room threw a bottle towards him.

items.title: Investigation launched into 'horrifying' death of streamer
items.standfirst: An investigation has been launched into the death of an internet streamer who was known for taking part in extreme online challenges.
items.content: An investigation has been launched into the death of an internet streamer who was known for taking part in extreme online challenges.

items.title: France probes death of streamer during live broadcast
items.standfirst: French authorities have opened an investigation into the death of a 46-year old man during a live stream on the Kick platform. Raphaël Graven had amassed hundreds of thousands of followers on social media after starring in live video streams during which he was sujected to physical violence, humiliation and sleep deprivation. FRANCE 24's Selina Sykes reports.
items.content: French authorities have opened an investigation into the death of a 46-year old man during a live stream on the Kick platform. Raphaël Graven had amassed hundreds of thousands of followers on social media after starring in live video streams during which he was sujected to physical violence, humiliation and sleep deprivation. FRANCE 24's Selina Sykes reports.

items.title: Investigation into 'horrifying' death of French streamer
items.standfirst: Raphaël Graven, also known as Jeanpormanove, was found dead at a residence in Contes, a village north of Nice, prosecutors said.
items.content: Raphaël Graven, also known as Jeanpormanove, was found dead at a residence in Contes, a village north of Nice, prosecutors said.

ai_summary: French authorities are investigating the death of a streamer.
The streamer, known as Jeanpormanove, died during a live stream.
The stream showed the man being mistreated.
The streamer had a large following on social media.
The death occurred in a residence north of Nice.

clusters.title: Paris rebuffs Netanyahu over accusations of antisemitism
clusters.neutral_headline: France Rebukes Israel Over Antisemitism Accusations

items.title: Paris rebuffs Netanyahu over accusations of antisemitism
items.standfirst: After Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused French President Emmanuel Macron of “fueling antisemitism” by backing recognition of a Palestinian state, the Élysée hit back. In a statement, the French presidency called the remarks “abject” and “erroneous,” stressing that France will always stand by its Jewish citizens and that Netanyahu’s claims “will not go unanswered.”
items.content: After Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused French President Emmanuel Macron of “fueling antisemitism” by backing recognition of a Palestinian state, the Élysée hit back. In a statement, the French presidency called the remarks “abject” and “erroneous,” stressing that France will always stand by its Jewish citizens and that Netanyahu’s claims “will not go unanswered.”

items.title: ‘Erroneous, abject and unacceptable’: France rebukes Israel over antisemitism allegations
items.standfirst: France, Israel trade barbs as Paris eyes Palestinian state recognition
items.content: France, Israel trade barbs as Paris eyes Palestinian state recognition

France called the remarks "abject" and "erroneous".
France will always stand by its Jewish citizens.
France is considering recognizing a Palestinian state.

items.title: Liverpool's Salah makes history as first three-time PFA player of the year winner
items.standfirst: Liverpool forward Mohamed Salah became the first player to win the Professional Footballers’ Association men’s player of the year award three times on Tuesday, after scoring 29 goals and 18 assists to seal the club’s 20th league title last season. The Egyptian also won in 2018 and 2022.

items.standfirst: Pierre Poilievre returns to House of Commons after shock April loss and narrower margin in Tory strongholdCanada’s Conservative leader, Pierre Poilievre, has won a closely watched byelection in the province of Alberta, giving him a chance to return to parliament after suffering a shock defeat in April’s federal election.Poilievre finished with 80.4% of the vote after Monday’s election in the riding of Battle River-Crowfoot, in the deeply Conservative western province. items.title: Air Canada flight attendants reach ‘tentative’ deal with airline to end strike
items.standfirst: Strike over wages and ground work has cancelled travel for 500,000 people worldwideAir Canada flight attendants say they have reached a “tentative” deal with the airline to end a strike over wages and ground work that has cancelled travel for half a million people worldwide.Roughly 10,000 flight attendants walked off the job after midnight Saturday, insisting Air Canada had failed to address their demands for higher pay and compensation for unpaid ground work, including during boarding. Continue reading...

items.title: Air Canada and flight attendants reach tentative deal to end strike
items.standfirst: The Air Canada strike has ended after flight attendants reached a tentative agreement with the airline, both parties said early Tuesday."The Strike has ended," the Canadian Union of Public Employees said in a Facebook post advising its membership to "fully cooperate with resumption of operations."
